intro: Gonocormus novoguineensis, commonly known as the New Guinea moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of New Guinea. It is characterized by its large, showy white flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and has a climbing habit, often found in humid, shaded forest environments. Its leaves are typically heart-shaped and have a velvety texture, while the fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds. The botanical features of Gonocormus novoguineensis make it a unique and ecologically significant species in its native habitat.
